{{Refimprove|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox news event |image = [[File:MapaZGMMexico.svg|250px]] |caption = Location of Guadalajara |date = April 22, 1992 |time = 10:05 - 11:16 ([[UTC-6]]) |place = Analco, Guadalajara, Jalisco, Mexico |also known as = Guadalajara gas explosion |first reporter = |filmed by = |participants = |outcome = |reported injuries = 500+ |reported death(s) = 206 |reported property damage = thousands of homes affected |burial = |inquiries = |inquest = |coroner = |verdict = |suspects = |charges = |convictions = 4 Pemex officials charged for negligence |publication bans = |litigation = |awards = |url = |website = |notes = }}
A series of ten explosions took place on April 22, 1992, in the downtown district of Analco Colonia Atlas in [[Guadalajara]] city, [[Jalisco]] state, Mexico. Numerous [[gasoline]] explosions in the [[sanitary sewer|sewer]] system and fires over four hours destroyed {{convert|8|km}} of streets.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r_lnqNFJPOcC|title=Managing Disaster Risk in Mexico: Market Incentives for Mitigation Investment|last=Kreimer|first=Alcira|date=1999|publisher=World Bank Publications|isbn=9780821344910|page=44|language=en}}</ref> Gante Street was the most damaged. By the accounting of [[Lloyd's of London]], the reported number of people killed was about 252 people although many estimate that the catastrophe actually caused at least 1000 deaths.<ref name=aria.dev>{{cite web|url=http://www.aria.developpement-durable.gouv.fr/wp-content/files_mf/FD_3543_guadalajara_1992_ang.pdf|title=Explosion of hydrocarbons in an urban sewerage network|last=|first=|date=December 2007|website=|publisher=|access-date=October 26, 2016}}</ref> About 500 to 600 people were missing,<ref name=aria.dev/> nearly 500 were injured and 15,000 were left homeless. The estimated monetary damage ranges between $300 million and $1 billion. The affected areas can be recognized by the more [[modern architecture]] in the areas that were destroyed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tech.mit.edu/V112/N22/mexico.22w.html |author=Peter Eisner |title=Nine officials charged in sewer-line explosions case |work=The Tech |publisher=Tech.mit.edu |date=April 28, 1992 |accessdate=2014-04-20}}</ref>
Four days before the explosion, residents started complaining of a strong gas-like smell coming from the sewers which became progressively more pungent over the course of those days. They were experiencing symptoms such as stinging in their eyes and throats; and nausea.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/sewers-explode-in-guadalajara|title=Sewers explode in Guadalajara - Apr 22, 1992 - HISTORY.com|newspaper=HISTORY.com|access-date=2016-10-26}}</ref> Some residents even found gasoline coming out of their water pipes. City workers were dispatched to check the sewers and found dangerously high levels of gasoline fumes. However, the city mayor did not feel it was necessary to evacuate the city because he felt that there was no risk of an explosion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.semp.us/publications/biot_reader.php?BiotID=356 |work=SEMP Biot #356 |title=The Guadalajara 1992 Sewer Gas Explosion Disaster |publisher=Semp.us |date=May 3, 2006 |accessdate=2015-12-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090210235229/http://www.semp.us/publications/biot_reader.php?BiotID=356 |archivedate=February 10, 2009 }}</ref>
== Chronology of events ==
Before the explosions, on April 19, Gante Street residents reported a strong stench of gasoline and plumes of white smoke coming out from the sewers to the City of Guadalajara. The next day, workers of the City Council and [[Civil Protection]] commenced two days of investigations in Gante Street; they found high levels of gasoline among other hydrocarbons, but announced it was not necessary to evacuate the area. At 10am on April 22, manhole covers in the street began to bounce and columns of white smoke started coming out of them.
At 10:05 on April 22, the first two explosions were recorded, the first on the corner of Calzada Independencia and Aldama Street, and the second at the intersection of Gante and 20 De Noviembre. A minute later the first call was received on the 060 Emergency Line and was forwarded to automatic voice messenger. A third explosion at 10:08 resulted in a bus, belonging to the Tuts Company, being projected through the air on the corner of Gante and Nicolas Bravo. Four minutes later another explosion was registered in Gonzalez Gallo Avenue. At 10:15 factory workers along Gonzalez Gallo Avenue began to evacuate, just before rescue teams and volunteers began to arrive in areas affected by the explosions. At 10:23 the fifth explosion occurred, at the intersection of Gante and Calzada del Ejercito. At 10:29 evacuations began in the Mexicaltzingo neighborhood, two minutes before the sixth explosion was recorded at the intersection of 5 De Febrero and Rio Bravo.
At 10:43 the seventh explosion occurred, at the corner of Ghent Street and Silverio Garcia. Just after more rescue teams arrived in the affected areas, the eighth explosion occurred at 11:02, at the intersection of Rio Nilo Avenue and the Rio Grande. After this explosion the neighborhoods of Atlas, Alamo Industrial, El Rosario, Quinta Velarde and Fraccionamiento Revolución; and the center of the municipality of [[Tlaquepaque]]; were evacuated. The last two explosions were at 11:16, one at the intersection of Rio Alamos and Rio Pecos, and the other at González Gallo and Rio Suchiate. In the afternoon, the fear of further tragedies made people across the [[Guadalajara Metropolitan Area|Guadalajara Metro Area]] uncover manholes for any remaining gases to escape. Residents of neighborhoods such as Zona Industrial, 18 De marzo, Fresno, 8 De Julio, Ferrocarril, La Nogalera, Morelos, Echeverria, Polanco, 5 de mayo and Miravalle are told to be aware of any unusual events.
After the explosions, there was great panic on April 25 among residents of the neighborhoods 5 De Mayo, el Dean, Echeverría and Polanco; firefighters asked people to avoid lighting any flames, due to a strong smell of gas. It was later confirmed to be a leak in a [[Pemex]] pipe.
==Investigation== An investigation into the disaster found that there were two precipitating causes:
* New water pipes, made of [[zinc]]-coated [[iron]], were built too close to an existing [[steel]] gasoline pipeline. The underground humidity caused these materials to create an [[electrolytic]] reaction, akin to that which occurs inside a [[zinc-carbon battery]]. As the reaction proceeded it eventually caused the steel pipe to [[corrosion|corrode]], creating a hole in the pipeline that permitted gasoline to leak into the ground and into the main sewer pipe. * The sewer pipe had been recently rebuilt into a U-shape so that the city could expand its underground metro railway system. Usually sewers are built in a slope so that gravity helps move waste along. In order to get the U-shape to work, an [[inverted siphon]] was placed so that fluids could be pushed against gravity. The design was flawed, however. While liquids were successfully pumped through, gases were not, and gas fumes would build up.
==Aftermath== In the aftermath, city officials and corporations blamed each other. Some people initially thought a cooking oil manufacturing company was leaking [[hexane]], a flammable liquid similar to (and a component of) gasoline, into the sewers, but this was later found to be erroneous. Numerous arrests were made in an attempt to indict those responsible for the blasts.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www1.umn.edu/humanrts/cases/17-03.html |title=Maria Estela Acosta Hernandez et. al. v. Mexico |publisher=University of Minnesota |date=February 20, 2003 |accessdate=2014-04-20}}</ref> Four [[Pemex]] officials were indicted and charged, on the basis of negligence. Ultimately, however, these people were cleared of all charges.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,975488,00.html |title=Pemex Is Blamed for The Sewer Explosion|publisher=Time.com |date=1992-05-11 |work=Time |accessdate=2014-04-20}}{{paywall}}</ref>
Many of the survivors that were affected by the explosions started a group called "La Asociacion 22 de Abril en Guadalajara" (the association of April 22 of Guadalajara).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://pagina24jalisco.com.mx/local/2014/05/07/niega-lilia-ruiz-abusos-contra-afectados-del-22-de-abril/|title=Niega Lilia Ruiz abusos contra afectados del 22 de abril {{!}} Página 24 Jalisco|website=pagina24jalisco.com.mx|access-date=2016-10-26}}</ref> This campaign was started by a survivor of the explosions named Lilia Ruiz Chávez, who as a result of the explosions lost her leg as well as her home. She started the group that has a total of 80 members not only because no one was convicted of this preventable incident but also because the victims of this tragedy were not receiving any compensation or assistance due to injuries sustained or loss as a result of the accident. The victims of this tragedy not only lost their homes but also their health and many lost loved ones as well. Although they are aware that no amount of money will bring back their relatives as states Chavez, the tragedy left them unable to care for themselves let alone afford their medication as a consequence of the incident. Chavez as well as the other survivors have been fighting for 24 years now for justice to be served. Because of the constant struggle and pressure from the victims toward [[Pemex]], the company that was initially blamed for the incident, finally agreed to pay out 40 million pesos to the group. Although Pemex claims this is a donation and no way does it mean they are taking blame for the incident.

{{infobox flood |image location= |image = Flood in Central Europe 20090619-30 precip acc.png |caption = Precipitation totals, June 19–30, 2009 |name=2009 European floods |duration=June 2009 |total fatalities=33 |areas affected=[[Czech Republic]], [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]], [[Austria]], [[Hungary]], [[Germany]], [[Romania]], [[Serbia]], [[Turkey]] |total damages=Unknown }} The '''2009 European floods''' were a series of natural disasters that took place in June 2009 in [[Central Europe]]. [[Austria]], the [[Czech Republic]], [[Germany]], [[Hungary]], [[Poland]], [[Romania]], [[Serbia]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Turkey]] were all affected. The heavy rains caused overflowing of the rivers [[Oder River|Oder]], [[Vistula]], [[Elbe]] and [[Danube]]. At least 12 people were killed in the [[Czech Republic]]<ref>{{cite news | title=Ten dead in Czech floods, central Europe on alert | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSTRE55O4O820090625 | work= | publisher=Reuters.com | date= 2009-06-25| accessdate=2009-06-26| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090629170650/https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSTRE55O4O820090625| archivedate= 29 June 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> and one in [[Poland]]{{Citation needed|date=June 2009}}.
The floods were the worst natural disaster in the Czech Republic since [[2002 European floods|2002]], when floods killed 17 people and caused billions of dollars of damage in [[Prague]].<ref name="At least 10 die in Czech floods"/> Those same floodwaters from the Czech Republic also affected [[Germany]], with [[Dresden]] being hit by its worst flooding for over a century and three thousand people evacuated from areas where water was said to be waist-deep.<ref name="Floods continue to threaten European cities">{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2002/0815/floods.html|title=Floods continue to threaten European cities|date=2002-08-15|accessdate=2009-06-29|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]}}</ref> Austria also experienced its heaviest rainfalls in half a century.<ref name="At least 10 die in Czech floods"/>
==Weather==
June 2009 was one of the rainiest months of June for Austria since weather records have been kept.<ref name="ZAMG-2.7">{{cite web|url=http://www.zamg.ac.at/aktuell/index.php?seite=1&artikel=ZAMG_2009-07-02GMT04:35 |accessdate=March 24, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090704000431/http://www.zamg.ac.at/aktuell/index.php?seite=1&artikel=ZAMG_2009-07-02GMT04%3A35 |title=Wetterübersicht Juni 2009: Rekordniederschläge im Norden |language=de |archivedate=July 4, 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref name="SN 2009-06-29-8">{{cite web|url=http://www.salzburg.com/nwas/archiv_artikel.php?xm=3509660|title=Archiv der Salzburger Nachrichten - SALZBURG.COM|author =Salzburger Nachrichten|publisher=Salzburg.com|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> After a very dry April,<ref name="ZAMG-Mai">{{cite web|url=http://www.zamg.ac.at/klima/klima_monat/wetterrueckblick/?jahr=2009&monat=04 |accessdate=March 24, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090709183141/http://www.zamg.ac.at/klima/klima_monat/wetterrueckblick/?jahr=2009&monat=04 |title=Wetterrückblick für April 2009 |language=de |archivedate=July 9, 2009 }}</ref> May had already been wet,<ref name="ZAMG-Juni">[http://www.zamg.ac.at/klima/klima_monat/wetterrueckblick/?jahr=2009&monat=05] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090712021632/http://www.zamg.ac.at/klima/klima_monat/wetterrueckblick/?jahr=2009&monat=05 |date=July 12, 2009 }}</ref> and in the middle of June, low pressure areas and thunderstorms followed. ''Quinton Low''<ref name="SN 2009-06-24-7">{{cite web|url=http://www.salzburg.com/nwas/archiv_artikel.php?xm=3508846|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090710012121/http://www.salzburg.com/nwas/archiv_artikel.php?xm=3508846|dead-url=yes|archive-date=10 July 2009|title=Archiv der Salzburger Nachrichten - SALZBURG.COM|author=Salzburger Nachrichten|publisher=Salzburg.com|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> ensured strong rainfall in the [[Eastern Alps]], the southern [[Carpathians]], and from the middle of the [[Balkan Peninsula]] to the [[Crimean Peninsula|Crimea]] and [[Baltic Sea]] regions between June 20 and June 30. It moved slowly over the [[Adriatic Sea]] toward the [[Black Sea]] forming an ''upper low'' – despite the typical muggy movement from the southeast and build-up of precipitation from the east and northeast, a classic flood situation that was missing the [[Genoa low]] of a ground low core.
The Quinton Low formed from June 20–22, through constriction of an upper low over the Alps towards the southeast. An Atlantic infusion of cold air had brought heavy precipitation<ref name="wetterzentrale GFS">{{cite web|url=http://www.wetterzentrale.de/topkarten/fsavneur.html|title=Wetter : Wetterzentrale : Top Karten : Prognose - GFS Europa|publisher=Wetterzentrale.de|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.met.fu-berlin.de/de/wetter/maps/Prognose_20090618.gif|format=GIF|title=Barometric map image|publisher=Met.fu-berlin.de|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> with snowfall down to elevations of 1500m. The separated upper low shifted over the mid-Adriatic on June 20 and 21<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.met.fu-berlin.de/de/wetter/maps/Prognose_20090620.gif|format=GIF|title=Barometric map image|publisher=Met.fu-berlin.de|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> and the central Balkans on June 22.<ref>[http://imkhp2.physik.uni-karlsruhe.de/~muehr/satpicsf/FV/EUR/200906211200_met8.jpg] {{dead link|date=November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.met.fu-berlin.de/de/wetter/maps/Prognose_20090622.gif|format=GIF|title=Barometric map image|publisher=Met.fu-berlin.de|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> Its front system, which was occluded from the east and then was guided to the northeast towards Central Europe, drove from June 22–24<ref>[http://imkhp2.physik.uni-karlsruhe.de/~muehr/satpicsf/FV/EUR/200906221200_met8.jpg] {{dead link|date=November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.met.fu-berlin.de/de/wetter/maps/Prognose_20090623.gif|format=GIF|title=Barometric map image|publisher=Met.fu-berlin.de|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wzkarten.de/pics/archive/2009/avn/Rtavn00120090623.png|format=PNG|title=Barometric weather image|publisher=Wzkarten.de|accessdate=28 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150620002600/http://www.wzkarten.de/pics/archive/2009/avn/Rtavn00120090623.png|archive-date=2015-06-20|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.met.fu-berlin.de/de/wetter/maps/Prognose_20090624.gif|format=GIF|title=Barometric map image|publisher=Met.fu-berlin.de|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> from the [[Lower Inn Valley]] to the [[Vienna Basin]] with heavy precipitation of over 100mm/48h, with 207mm/48h in [[Lunz am See]]. Locally, this phase was similar to the [[2005 European floods]], although in that year there was a faster rise.<ref name="SN 2009-06-24-7"/>
Starting on June 25, the low moved over the [[Black Sea]]. On June 25 and 26,<ref>[http://imkhp2.physik.uni-karlsruhe.de/~muehr/satpicsf/FV/EUR/200906251200_met8.jpg] {{dead link|date=November 2014}}</ref> the precipitation was concentrated in the area around [[Belgrade]] and Southern Hungary. In Austria and the Czech Republic, the situation eased. On June 27 and 28,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.met.fu-berlin.de/de/wetter/maps/Prognose_20090627.gif|format=GIF|title=Barometric map image|publisher=Met.fu-berlin.de|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref><ref>[https://archive.is/20120630213432/http://imkhp2.physik.uni-karlsruhe.de/~muehr/satpicsf/FV/EUR/200906271200_met8.jpg] </ref> a front moved towards Southern Poland and the Baltic states, and further precipitation-heavy air masses once again struck the Czech Republic, Austria, and Serbia, as well as Central [[Bulgaria]] and [[Moldova]] on June 29.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.met.fu-berlin.de/de/wetter/maps/Prognose_20090629.gif|format=GIF|title=Barometric map image|publisher=Met.fu-berlin.de|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wzkarten.de/pics/archive/2009/avn/Rtavn00120090629.png|format=PNG|title=Barometric weather image|publisher=Wzkarten.de|accessdate=28 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150620000904/http://www.wzkarten.de/pics/archive/2009/avn/Rtavn00120090629.png|archive-date=2015-06-20|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
The stable and stationary weather situation did not disintegrate until after June 29. However, the air mass over Central and Eastern Europe remained extremely moist and unstable such that heavy thunderstorms repeatedly drove further local floods in the following days. Local areas of heavy rain of up to 50mm in a few hours were recorded across Central Europe until the first two weeks of July. The end of the weather phase did not occur until the passing of the low ''Rainer'' over England and the North Sea<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.met.fu-berlin.de/de/wetter/maps/Prognose_20090703.gif|format=GIF|title=Barometric map image|publisher=Met.fu-berlin.de|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.met.fu-berlin.de/de/wetter/maps/Prognose_20090704.gif|format=GIF|title=Barometric map image|publisher=Met.fu-berlin.de|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> and low ''Steffen'' over Southern Scandinavia,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.met.fu-berlin.de/de/wetter/maps/Prognose_20090708.gif|format=GIF|title=Barometric map image|publisher=Met.fu-berlin.de|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref><ref>[http://imkhp2.physik.uni-karlsruhe.de/~muehr/satpicsf/DWD/2009_IR/200907081200ir.jpg] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111020120943/http://imkhp2.physik.uni-karlsruhe.de/~muehr/satpicsf/DWD/2009_IR/200907081200ir.jpg |date=October 20, 2011 }}</ref> which the slowly advancing weather system surrounded from July 3 to the 9th.
<gallery caption="Cumulative precipitation of the three weather event segments" widths="150"> File:Flood in Central Europe 20090619-24 precip acc.png|Low core Adriatic/Balkans June 19–24, 2009 File:Flood in Central Europe 20090625-30 precip acc.png|Upper low Black Sea June 25–30, 2009 File:Flood in Central Europe 20090701-09 precip acc.png|Unstable post-phase and advancing Atlantic low July 1–9, 2009 </gallery>
== By country == [[File:Hochwasser 2009 Traisen Wilhelmsburg.JPG|200px|thumb|right|[[Driftwood]] in [[Wilhelmsburg, Austria|Wilhelmsburg]], [[Lower Austria]]]]
===Austria=== On Tuesday June 23, the strong rise began to impact the tributaries that lead from the south to the Danube, and flood warnings were triggered on the night of June 24 in many places in the [[Upper Austrian Prealps|Upper]] and [[Vienna Woods|Lower Austrian Prealps]].<ref name ="fireworld">{{cite web|url=http://www.fireworld.at/cms/story.php?id=22502&menu=4|title=sterreich: Hochwasser-Einstze Juni 2009|publisher=Fireworld.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> The state warning centers were reinforced. By the morning of June 24, about 4,000 firefighters were already operating in [[Upper Austria]] and [[Lower Austria]]. Armed Forces helicopters were also in use.
In Upper Austria, the [[Krems (Lower Austria)|Krems]] and [[Traun (river)|Traun]] rivers partially came together at the banks. The level of the tributaries was rising while the Danube was steady. Seven districts in Lower Austria were already affected. The rivers [[Ybbs]], Melk, Erlauf, [[Traisen (river)|Traisen]], and Perschling were especially flooded. [[Ybbsitz]] had been closed off from the outside world since 3AM.<ref name="SN 2009-06-30-8">{{cite web|url=http://www.salzburg.com/nwas/archiv_artikel.php?xm=3509205|title=Archiv der Salzburger Nachrichten - SALZBURG.COM|author=Salzburger Nachrichten|publisher=Salzburg.com|accessdate=28 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090709140931/http://www.salzburg.com/nwas/archiv_artikel.php?xm=3509205|archive-date=2009-07-09|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> At the Danube (Strudengau, [[Wachau]]), the available mobile flood prevention equipment was assembled as much as possible. In [[Styria]], only individual actions were reported, mainly pumping operations but also elimination of mudslides.
By June 25, the persistent rainfall was over. Instead, increasingly short heavy rains with large masses of water were recorded. Since the ground was no longer receptive to water, the aftereffects of these precipitations were similarly devastating. In Upper Austria, the situation calmed because the level of the tributaries was slowly falling towards normal levels. In [[Steyr]], the level had sunk to the quay, 1.4m less than the previous day. The Danube had reached its highest level of 6.9m overnight in [[Mauthausen]] and also sank slowly. The center of the flood shifted towards Wachau as the precipitation itself moved towards the east. 253 of the 326 fire departments in [[Burgenland]] were called on for flood operations within 24 hours.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bfkdo-gs.at/images/downloads/20090624_pa_unwetter_lfv.pdf |format=PDF |title=Unwettereinsätze im Burgenland : Größter Einsatz in der Geschichte des Landesfeuerwehrverbandes 253 der 326 burgenländischen Feuerwehren im Einsatz |publisher=Bkfdo-gs.at |accessdate=28 November 2014 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The [[Albertina, Vienna|Albertina Museum]] in [[Vienna]] evacuated 950,000 artworks by artists such as Monet and Renoir.<ref name="At least 10 die in Czech floods">{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2009/0625/breaking18.htm|title=At least 10 die in Czech floods|date=2009-06-25|accessdate=2009-06-29|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''}}</ref>
On June 26, further floods affected areas stretching from [[Mostviertel]] to Burgenland, particularly in the [[Güssing District]] where whole tracts of land were under up to a meter of water, while [[Strem]] was surrounded by masses of water.<ref name="SN 2009-06-30-8"/> The Armed Forces assisted the fire departments with 200 men. In the Lower Austrian Klingfurth near [[Wiener Neustadt]], homes threatened by a landslide had to be evacuated. The [[Adria-Wien Pipeline]], which lies in the affected hillside, had to be turned off for security reasons. In Styria, in which about 400 landslides were recorded since the beginning of the storm, the situation calmed a bit as the day turned to evening.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oesterreich.orf.at/stories/371300/|title=Hochwasser: Keine Pause für die Helfer - oesterreich.ORF.at|publisher=Oesterreich.orf.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref>
On Saturday June 27, two dams of the [[Leitha]] river in [[Bruck an der Leitha District]] were broken open so that water could flow into an uninhabited area in order to relieve the river.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://noe.orf.at/stories/371554/|title=Donauzubringer könnten wieder ansteigen - oesterreich.ORF.at|publisher=Noe.orf.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> On Sunday night, a fatality was reported.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://noe.orf.at/stories/371448/|title=Wasserflut fordert Opfer: 16-Jähriger stirbt - oesterreich.ORF.at|publisher=Noe.orf.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref>
Further installments of rain were encountered after the weekend. The assistance of the Armed Forces concentrated on the areas around [[Feldbach District]] and [[Fürstenfeld District]]. [[Upper Styria]] was also increasingly affected. The village of [[Radmer]] was without power and completely inaccessible after heavy mudslides. Floods and obstructions also surrounded [[Mariazell]] and [[Hieflau]]. The situation at the [[Enns (river)|Enns]] intensified again. On the afternoon of Monday June 29, the level of the Steyr was again over 4m. Wachau also went into another flood warning.<ref name="SN 2009-06-30-8"/> On the night of June 30, the Alpine railway station was flooded for the second time in the span of a few days<ref name=StPoeltenKatastrophe>{{cite web|url=http://www.st-poelten.gv.at/Content.Node/presse/Hochwasser.php.23264.php|title=Home - Landeshauptstadt St. Pölten, Niederösterreich|publisher=St-poelten.gv.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> after the strongest-ever measured rainfall in [[St. Pölten]]. The [[ÖBB]] again closed down the operation of the [[Mariazellerbahn]].<ref name=orfnoe371845>{{cite web|url=http://noe.orf.at/stories/371845/|title=St. Pölten und Wilhelmsburg wieder betroffen - oesterreich.ORF.at|publisher=Noe.orf.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref>
On Tuesday, further landslides were able to be stopped with the help of [[Czech hedgehog]]s. Nevertheless, numerous buildings could still not be cleared as habitable. Due to scattered storms in [[Graz-Umgebung District]], there were also frequent lightning strikes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://steiermark.orf.at/stories/372319/|title=Heftige Gewitter: Wieder Hangrutschungen - oesterreich.ORF.at|publisher=Steiermark.orf.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref>
On Friday July 3, Wachau was affected by the storm for the second time within two weeks. [[Spitz, Austria|Spitz]], which had been previously flooded by the Danube, was flooded this time by the usually only 30 cm deep Spitzerbach, which swelled to 4m after thunderstorms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://noe.orf.at/stories/372769/|title=Erneut lokale Überflutungen und Vermurungen - oesterreich.ORF.at|publisher=Noe.orf.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> An 81-year-old man who was swept away was not found until July 12 in the Danube.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://noe.orf.at/stories/374579/|title=Hochwasseropfer vermutlich gefunden - oesterreich.ORF.at|publisher=Oesterreich.orf.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> Also, in [[Waldviertel]] and [[Steyr-Land District]], severe thunderstorms occurred with heavy precipitation, which again required the use of over 2,000 firefighters.<ref name="orf 372868">{{cite web|url=http://oesterreich.orf.at/stories/372868/|title=Ein Toter in Niederösterreich befürchtet - oesterreich.ORF.at|publisher=Oesterreich.orf.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref>
On Monday July 6, the strongest rainfall in 200 years began in the afternoon hours. Parts of Lower Austria, [[Vienna]], and Northern Burgenland were especially affected.<ref name=derstandard070709>{{cite web|url=http://derstandard.at/fs/1246541405761/Jahrhunderregen-am-Montag-St-Poelten-saeuft-ab|title=St. Pölten säuft ab|work=Derstandard.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> St. Pölten was again declared a disaster area, as large parts of the metropolitan area were flooded.<ref name=stpoelten>{{cite web|url=http://www.st-poelten.gv.at/Content.Node/presse/Krisenstab.php|title=Home - Landeshauptstadt St. Pölten, Niederösterreich|publisher=St-poelten.gv.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> The Nadelbach flooded the cadastral communities Nadelbach and Hafing. The surroundings of the Alpine Railway Station were yet again under water. Areas that had never before had to suffer through flooding were also unexpectedly under water on July 6. Europaplatz and Schießstadtring in St. Pölten had to be closed off; a 7m-wide stream had carved itself out leading from the Alpine Railway Station to the center of the city. The regional court and the prison were also threatened by high water.<ref name=presse070709>{{cite web|url=http://diepresse.com/home/panorama/oesterreich/493293/index.do?_vl_backlink=/home/panorama/oesterreich/index.do|title=St. Pölten: Ärger als die Jahrhundertflut|work=DiePresse.com|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> A further danger existed at the [[EVN Group]] substation as the water level had almost brought power production to a halt. The B1a tunnel under the government Landhaus district was blocked due to the flood. The [[Western Railway (Austria)|Western Railway]] had to be closed down for two hours in the evening.<ref name=derstandard070709/> Additional problems arose due to the rise of the groundwater level associated with the flooding, which also reached a historical peak.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://noe.orf.at/stories/373507/|title=Grundwasserspiegel in St. Pölten enorm hoch - oesterreich.ORF.at|publisher=Noe.orf.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref>
Severe weather warnings were issued on Thursday July 7 that were similar in scope to the days before. This time however, the storm affected the Upper Austrian area more, where especially extensive damage had been done by hail in agricultural areas in [[Gmunden]], [[Vöcklabruck]], and [[Wels]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ooe.orf.at/stories/373644/|title=Millionenschaden nach Hagelunwetter - oesterreich.ORF.at|publisher=Ooe.orf.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> In [[Dürnstein]] in Wachau, there were rockslides at Vogelbergsteig, which blocked both the Danube Highway and the Danube Railway.<ref>[http://oe1.orf.at/inforadio/109114.html?filter=3] {{dead link|date=November 2014}}</ref> The B3 became once again freely passable on July 10 after explosions that removed loose rock from the wall. However, the Danube Railway required longer repair work.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://noe.orf.at/stories/374290/|title=B3 nach Felssturz wieder befahrbar - oesterreich.ORF.at|publisher=Noe.org.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref>
On July 10, the situation in Styria again took a turn for the worse. There was further rainfall, especially in Feldbach District.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://steiermark.orf.at/stories/374178/|title=Erneut Hangrutschungen im Bezirk Feldbach - oesterreich.ORF.at|publisher=Steiermark.orf.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> There were about 600 landslides in Styria around this timeframe.

====Damage and relief efforts====
Damage estimates were first released after two weeks. The damage in Burgenland amounted to over €2,500,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://burgenland.orf.at/stories/373166/|title=Schadensbilanz nach Hochwasser - oesterreich.ORF.at|publisher=Burgenland.orf.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> In Lower Austria, about 3,000 claims were registered with a total claim amount of about €60,000,000. Because of this, the assistance for Lower Austria was increased from an estimated €2,500,000 to €10,000,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://noe.orf.at/stories/373442/|title=Hochwasserhilfe des Landes wird aufgestockt - oesterreich.ORF.at|publisher=Oesterreich.orf.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> In Upper Austria, damage claims were expected to be about €20,000,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oesterreich.orf.at/stories/374233/|title=Nach dem Hochwasser: Schaden wird sichtbar - oesterreich.ORF.at|publisher=Oesterreich.orf.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> In Styria, the amount was about €10,000,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://steiermark.orf.at/stories/373945/|title=Bezirk Feldbach: Noch keine Entwarnung - oesterreich.ORF.at|publisher=Steiermark.orf.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> The other federal states did not report damage totals.
Since disaster management in Austria takes place mainly at the federal state level, figures for all of Austria are not readily available. Countrywide figures were only released for the Armed Forces. 137,000 relief hours were worked in the assistance operation from June 23 to July 9. On average, about 700 soldiers were deployed at any time countrywide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oesterreich.orf.at/stories/373943/|title=Soldaten waren 137.000 Stunden im Einsatz - oesterreich.ORF.at|publisher=Oesterreich.orf.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> 311,000 relief hours were worked by firefighters and disaster assistance services in the largest federal state Lower Austria alone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://noe.orf.at/stories/374312/|title=Tausende Helfer packten an - oesterreich.ORF.at|publisher=Noe.orf.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> The [[Austrian Red Cross]] also helped with many volunteers and crisis intervention teams. Likewise, Team Austria volunteers were put to work in the relief effort.<ref>[https://archive.is/20120712022100/http://oe3.orf.at/teamoesterreich/stories/372677/] </ref>
The fact that at the beginning of August in Lower Austria alone twelve streets and three railways were obstructed shows how extensive the infrastructure damage was. The repair work took weeks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://noe.orf.at/stories/379495/|title=Nach Unwettern weiterhin Straßen gesperrt - oesterreich.ORF.at|publisher=Noe.org.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref>
=== Czech Republic ===
In the Czech Republic, persistent heavy rainfall beginning on June 22 led to the rise of smaller Vltavan tributaries in the [[Bohemian Forest]] and the Nové Hrady Mountains. A flood warning was issued for the [[South Bohemian Region]]. The highest level was reached in the rivers [[Malše]], Blatnice, and Černá. [[České Budějovice]] was also affected by the warning.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tschechien-online.org/news/15385-hochwasserwarnung-tschechien/|title=Hochwasserwarnung in Tschechien|work=Tschechien Online|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> In the evening, the Rožnovská Bečva rose about 1.2m in [[Valašské Meziříčí]] and its water level at the estuary in the [[Bečva]] rose to ten times normal. The [[Vsetínská Bečva]] also swelled and several streets were flooded in [[Vsetín]], Valašské Meziříčí, and [[Rožnov pod Radhoštěm]]. In [[Zubří (Vsetín District)|Zubří]], numerous cars were overcome by the water. There were fatalities in [[Černotín]] and Valašské Meziříčí. In [[Český Krumlov]], the [[Vltava]] reached six times the normal water amount, with 63 m³/s. Near [[Větřní]], a dinghy containing three occupants capsized, one of which drowned.
[[File:Nový Jičín, den po povodni 2009.jpg|200px|thumb|right|Flash flood in [[Nový Jičín]] on June 25, 2009, the morning after]]
The floods in North [[Moravia]] and [[Silesia]] took on a different character. In the span of two hours on June 24, strong rainfall brought flash floods with up to 80L/m² of rain at the streams Jičínka and Zrzávka. The level of the Jičínka swelled to 5.5m and thereby exceeded the [[1997 Central European flood]] by 2m. In [[Jeseník nad Odrou]], the brook Luha rose to 2m in the span of a half-hour; four people died in that community, three by drowning. People also died in [[Nový Jičín]], [[Bernartice nad Odrou]], [[Životice u Nového Jičína]], and [[Kunín]]. The floods also created extensive damage in districts of Nový Jičín such as Bludovice, Žilina, [[Hodslavice]], and [[Mořkov]].
Other rivers temporarily rose over their banks after strong local rainfall. In [[Bohemian Switzerland]], the [[Kamenice (Labe)|Kamenice]] flooded parts of [[Janská]] on the evening of July 1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.obec-janska.cz/index.php?page%3Dpovoden |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-03-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090905004138/http://www.obec-janska.cz/index.php?page=povoden |archivedate=2009-09-05 |df= }} Bilder von Hochwasser in Janská</ref> On July 6th, sudden thunderstorms hit [[Ústí nad Labem Region]], where a state of emergency had to be called in some places. West and South Bohemia were also severely threatened in places like [[Tábor]]. The authorities feared a burst of dams of artificial lakes and considered evacuating the affected villages.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tschechien-online.org/news/15467-howasser-serie-tschechien-reisst-nicht/|title=Hochwasser-Serie in Tschechien reit nicht ab|work=Tschechien Online|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref>
Parts of West and South Bohemia as well as Central Moravia were also greatly affected by the flood. In the region, dams of a series of artificially created lakes threatened to break. The authorities considered the evacuation of more villages on Tuesday night.
Overall, fourteen people died in the Czech Republic due to the impact of the flooding.<ref>{{cite web|first=Rosie|last=Johnston|url=http://www.radio.cz/en/section/news/more-flash-floods-strike-north-bohemia|title=More flash floods strike north Bohemia|work=Radio Prague|date=5 July 2009|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> The [[Olomouc Region]] and the [[Moravian-Silesian Region]] were particularly affected in the drainage basins of the [[Oder]] and the [[Morava (river)|Morava]] where numerous streets and rail lines were disrupted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tschechien-online.org/news/15400-hochwasser-tschechien-fordert-zwolf-todesopfer/|title=Hochwasser in Tschechien fordert 12 Todesopfer|work=Tschechien Online|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref>
In the first estimates, the total damage was estimated to be 5-6 billion [[Czech koruna]] (about €230,000,000).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ceskenoviny.cz/news/zpravy/czech-regions-to-coordinate-steps-after-floods/386578?id=386573|title=Hašek: Kraje budou koordinovat obnovu po záplavách|language=Czech|work=Czech News Agency|date=5 July 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090712022540/http://www.ceskenoviny.cz/news/zpravy/czech-regions-to-coordinate-steps-after-floods/386578?id=386573|archivedate=12 July 2009}}</ref>
Hepatitis vaccinations were commenced for children in severely affected areas in order to prevent an outbreak of the disease.<ref>{{cite web|first=Daniela|last=Lazarová|url=http://www.radio.cz/en/section/news/children-in-flood-regions-inoculated-against-hepatitis|title=Children in flood regions inoculated against hepatitis|work=Radio Prague|date=6 July 2009|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref>
On July 24, the lowest flood warning level was lifted in Nový Jičín Region.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radio.cz/de/artikel/118638|title=Radio Prag - Trotz Hochwasserschäden kehrt normales Leben in Region Nový Jičín zurück|publisher=Radio.cz|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> Criticism of the speed of response by firefighters and municipalities was prevalent, as citizens were not informed about impending floods. The Environmental Minister [[Ladislav Miko]] confirmed that the meteorological internet server broke down at a critical time.<ref>{{cite web|first=Jan|last=Velinger|url=http://www.radio.cz/en/section/news/hospodarske-noviny-flood-commission-recommends-30-million-be-used-to-improve-communication-between-authorities-during-flood-crises|title=Hospodářské noviny: flood commission recommends 30 million be used to improve communication between authorities during flood crises|work=Radio Prague|date=24 July 2009|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref>

===Germany=== By June 23, the first warnings in [[Bavaria]] had already come as precipitation amounted to 70L/m<sup>2</sup> in 24 hours. In the mountains, snowfall was observed. On the Zugspitze, 60 cm of new snow fell. The first floods came at the [[Inn (river)|Inn]]. [[Altötting (district)|Altötting]], [[Berchtesgadener Land]], [[Cham (district)|Cham]], and particularly [[Traunstein (district)|Traunstein]] were affected by the flooding owing to rising tributaries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/bayern/577/473095/text/|title=Hochwasser in Bayern befürchtet - Wasser ohne Ende|work=Süddeutsche.de|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref>
On Thursday night, June 25, the level of the Danube rose in [[Passau]], such that the warning level reached 3 (definition: individual built-up properties or basements are flooded, blocking of local transport channels, or isolated use of water or dam defense is required). On Thursday, the flooding of the Danube and the [[Isar]] moved the warning level to 2 (definition: agriculture and forestry land is flooded or light traffic delays on main traffic roads and local roads). Throughout Thursday, the water level sank in Passau, however the recession was slow.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://de.news.yahoo.com/1/20090625/twl-hochwasser-in-bayern-auf-rckzug-1be00ca.html |title=Yahoo Nachrichten - Aktuelle Nachrichten & Meldungen |work=Yahoo Nachrichten Deutschland |accessdate=28 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090628145320/http://de.news.yahoo.com/1/20090625/twl-hochwasser-in-bayern-auf-rckzug-1be00ca.html |archivedate=28 June 2009 |df= }}</ref>
=== Hungary === [[File:Esztergom 2009 flood 2.JPG|200px|thumb|right|[[Nándor Zsolt Music School]] surrounded by water in [[Esztergom]]]] The first flood notifications in Hungary came on June 25. The [[Rába]] reached the highest ever measured level in [[Szentgotthárd]] on Thursday morning. This was about 30 cm higher than in a large flood in 1965. Due to the temporary expansion of flood protection and because the high water level did not persist, there was no expected risk. The Hungarian Western Railway still had to close down operation between Szentgotthárd and [[Jennersdorf]] because the rails were undermined in numerous places. In [[Komárom-Esztergom County]], the first flood warning level was called. The [[Leitha]] in Hungarian territory was not affected.
On June 26, a cautious all-clear was announced for the Danube between [[Esztergom]] and [[Budapest]] because the water levels remained lower than had been feared. The peak was expected on the night of June 27 into the 28th and was estimated to be 40–50 cm deeper than in the devastating floods of 2006. Nevertheless, precautions were taken in numerous important locations, such as [[Szentendre Island]].
On the morning of Sunday, June 28, the Danube reached its high point which was 25% less than the floods in 2006. Flood warnings were in effect for a stretch of 528 kilometers of the Danube in Hungary. In [[Nagymaros]], the level rose 5.33m, while the level in Budapest rose 6.96m. The increase had been expected to be 7.04m for a short time. In the upper Danube areas, the level sank noticeably around this time. In Budapest alone, the floods led to the blockage of the two quays.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pesterlloyd.net/2009_26/0926hochmontag/0926hochmontag.html|title=Hochwasser in Ungarn 2009, Donau, Budapest - Pester Lloyd|publisher=Pesterlloyd.net|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref>
On July 2 there were alerts along 853 kilometers. 36 kilometers of third degree alerts near the river [[Lajta]], second degree on the Danube at [[Dunakiliti]], [[Győr]], [[Komárom]], [[Esztergom]], [[Budapest]] and on the river Rába at [[Sárvár]], first degree alerts from the Ipoly river mouth to the southern border of Hungary.<ref>{{cite web|title=853 kilométernyi szakaszon van árvízvédelmi készültség - hir3.hu - Megbízható hírforrás, értéket közvetít |url=http://hir3.hu/index.php?hir=magazin&hirid=25973&kat=1 |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5iXakWyex?url=http://hir3.hu/index.php?hir=magazin&hirid=25973&kat=1 |archivedate=2009-07-25 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-07-03 |df= }}</ref>
=== Poland ===
On June 23, smaller rivers rose in the area of [[Rzeszów]] and in [[Lower Silesian Voivodeship]]. After strong rain fell in the [[Owl Mountains]] (at the rate of 60mm/h in [[Walim, Lower Silesian Voivodeship|Walim]], for example), flood warnings were called for the Piława at Mościsko (Faulbrück) and the Bystrzyca Świdnicka at Lubachów (Breitenhain). In Świdnica, Bystrzyca Street flooded. Further damage was seen in [[Wałbrzych]] and [[Jelenia Góra]].
The Polish National Security Center stated that rivers exceeded warning levels in forty-three areas, whilst alarm levels were exceeded in a further twenty places.<ref name="At least 10 die in Czech floods"/> A total of fifty families were evacuated in [[Kraków]]. Water submerged a railway station in [[Upper Silesia]].
=== Romania === Flood warnings were issued for 22 and 23 June for 21 [[Counties of Romania|counties]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.jurnalul.ro/stire-meteo/avertizarea-hidrologica-de-inundatii-pentru-21-de-judete-se-mentine-pana-miercuri-la-pranz-512355.html "Avertizarea hidrologică de inundaţii pentru 21 de judeţe se menţine până miercuri la prânz" ("Flood Warning for 21 Counties Maintained until Wednesday at Noon")], ''Jurnalul Naţional'', 23 June 2009; accessed 30 June 2009</ref> Amidst rain and hail, warnings were also issued for the [[Buzău River|Buzău]] and [[Ialomiţa River|Ialomiţa]] rivers for 29 and 30 June.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.jurnalul.ro/stire-meteo/avertizarea-hidrologica-de-inundatii-pentru-21-de-judete-se-mentine-pana-miercuri-la-pranz-512355.html "Cod galben de inundaţii pe râurile Buzău şi Ialomiţa. Marţi sunt aşteptate ploi şi grindină" ("Code Yellow for Flooding on Buzău and Ialomiţa Rivers. Rain and Hail Expected Tuesday")], ''Ziua'', 29 June 2009; accessed 30 June 2009</ref>
===Serbia=== Serbia was also hit with heavy rainfall by the storms. Places like [[Belgrade]] and [[Novi Sad]] in the north of the country were mainly affected, but [[Valjevo]] was also affected 90 km southeast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/eng/news/society-article.php?yyyy=2009&mm=06&dd=30&nav_id=60184 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120801124815/http://www.b92.net/eng/news/society-article.php?yyyy=2009&mm=06&dd=30&nav_id=60184 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=1 August 2012 |title=B92 - News - Storms hit northern Serbia |work=B92 |accessdate=28 November 2014 }}</ref>
===Slovakia=== Flood warnings were issued for parts of Northwest and far West Slovakia on June 24<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sme.sk/c/4905956/severozapadnemu-slovensku-hrozia-dazde-a-povodne.html|title=SME.sk - Severozpadnmu Slovensku hrozia dade a povodne|author =SME - Petit Press, a.s.|work=www.sme.sk|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> and extended to the [[Danubian Lowland]] on the 25th.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://spravy.pravda.sk/dunaj-pri-devine-prekrocil-7-5-metra-plati-vystraha-pre-povodnami-p87-/sk_domace.asp|title=Domáce|author =P E R E X , a. s.|work=Pravda.sk|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> They became effective on June 26 for the entire length of the Danube and at the Morava.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://spravy.pravda.sk/dunaj-sa-zahryzol-do-bratislavy-pri-devine-uz-prekrocil-osem-metrov-1gr-/sk_domace.asp?c=A090625_164004_sk_domace_p23|title=Dunaj sa zahryzol do Bratislavy. Pri Devíne už prekročil osem metrov|author =P E R E X , a. s.|work=Pravda.sk|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> In [[Čirč]] in the [[Prešov Region]] near the Polish border, two people had already been killed on June 23. A brother and sister drowned as the sister tried to rescue her brother.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spectator.sk/articles/view/32482/10/brother_and_sister_drown_in_east_slovak_flood.html|title=Brother and sister drown in East Slovak flood|author1=Lubomir Makky |author2=Mark Northrop |publisher=Spectator.sk|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref>
In [[Devín]], a suburb of [[Bratislava]], the level of the Danube was 8.3m on June 26.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spectator.sk/articles/view/35761/10/slovakia_faces_impending_flood_along_danube_on_thursday.html|title=Slovakia faces impending flood along Danube on Thursday|author1=Lubomir Makky |author2=Mark Northrop |publisher=Spectator.sk|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> Alongside Devín, [[Petržalka]], [[Šariš]], and [[Dunajská Streda]] were affected by a storm.
On June 27 and 28, the flood shifted to [[Bardejov]], [[Tvrdošín]], and [[Námestovo]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aktualne.centrum.sk/domov/regiony/clanek.phtml?id=1185209 |title=Povodne ničili Oravu a okolie Bardejova |work=Aktuálne.sk |accessdate=28 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090903103248/http://aktualne.centrum.sk/domov/regiony/clanek.phtml?id=1185209 |archivedate=3 September 2009 |df= }}</ref> The communities of [[Rabča]] and [[Oravská Polhora]] were particularly at risk as two bridges had been destroyed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://spravy.pravda.sk/velka-voda-na-orave-vyvracala-stromy-a-nicila-cesty-f8y-/sk_domace.asp?|title=Domáce|author =P E R E X , a. s.|work=Pravda.sk|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> On the 29th, [[Kežmarok]], [[Spišská Belá]], [[Ľubica]], [[Stará Bystrica]], and [[Radôstka]] were affected by landslides and flooding and there were additional storms in [[Senica]] and [[Skalica]].<ref>[http://spravy.pravda.sk/burky-sposobili-dalsie-skody-na-kysuciach-i-vychode-slovenska-pb3-/sk_domace.asp?c=A090629_194338_sk_domace_p23Búrky] {{dead link|date=November 2014}}</ref>
A 20-year-old Slovak drowned in the Ružín reservoir.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://spravy.pravda.sk/na-dunajci-sa-rozlomila-plt-s-turistami-utopil-sa-cesky-dochodca-p8t-/sk_ckronika.asp|title=Čierna kronika|author =P E R E X , a. s.|work=Pravda.sk|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> A Czech died as a tourist raft sank in the border river [[Dunajec]]. One person also died in [[Stará Ľubovňa]] near the Polish border.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.netzeitung.de/politik/ausland/154422.html?Hochwasser_auch_in_der_Slowakei |title=Hochwasser auch in der Slowakei |language=de |date=July 30, 2001 |accessdate=March 24, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090713050051/http://www.netzeitung.de/politik/ausland/154422.html?Hochwasser_auch_in_der_Slowakei |archivedate=July 13, 2009 }}</ref>
===Turkey=== A flash flood in [[Istanbul]] started on September 9. Heavy rains caused water levels to rise six feet, flooding a major highway and commercial district in the city's Ikitelli district. Hundreds of people climbed onto rooftops, and many desperate motorists struggled to escape their vehicles and run to safety. Others drowned in their own vehicles. Many people taking refuge on rooftop of them were airlifted to safety by rescue helicopters. Rescue workers using inflatable boats also travelled through the flooded streets, picking up survivors. Some rescuers used ropes to drag people across the torrent to safety. Four helicopters and eight boats were used for rescue work. Istanbul firefighters recovered seven bodies at a truck parking lot littered with upended trucks. The bodies of seven women were found in a van outside a textile factory. The van had been taking them to their jobs, when the flood hit. Police were deployed throughout the city to prevent looting. Two other people died in Istanbul's Catalca suburb and six others were swept away by the flood. 20 people died, 8 were listed as missing, and 20 were injured.<ref>[http://www.news.yahoo.comk/s/ap/20090909/ap_on_re_eu/eu_turkey_floods] {{dead link|date=November 2013}}</ref>
==Further storms== Storms followed this series of floods that had no connection with the weather referenced above but mostly affected the same areas.
On the night of July 23, a storm front moved from Germany into Austria, the Czech Republic, and Poland that arose due to previously prevalent unusually high temperatures. It impacted the area through hail and storms and partially also through heavy rainfall.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fireworld.at/cms/story.php?id=23043|title=Sbg: Groeinsatz nach Hagelsturm im Flachgau|publisher=Fireworld.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> In Lower Austria, where such fronts usually dissipate, the front strengthened and the storms hit the Vienna metropolitan area. The population was completely unprepared when the storm struck because it did not appear in any weather models. People were injured or even killed mainly by uprooted trees. Agriculture was also hit hard with damages. Widespread power outages were recorded. The Austrian insurance companies faced damages of around €20,000,000 in the agricultural industry alone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.orf.at/090724-40808/?href=http://www.orf.at/090724-40808/40809txt_story.html|title=Tennisballgro&zlig;e Hagelkörner|publisher=Orf.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The Austrian hail insurance companies also faced the largest single event in the last 60 years from a cost of damages perspective.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hagel.at/site/index.cfm?objectid=AC305148-AE47-DA47-1924EF91D0838ED2&refid=2C81258A-3005-4277-CFC40E405708392F|title=Hagelversicherung: Unwetter vom 23. Juli führte zu katastrophalen Hagelschäden in Österreichs Landwirtschaft|publisher=Hagel.at|accessdate=28 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160128115001/http://www.hagel.at/site/index.cfm?objectid=AC305148-AE47-DA47-1924EF91D0838ED2&refid=2C81258A-3005-4277-CFC40E405708392F|archive-date=2016-01-28|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> On July 25, the emergency personnel of firefighters and the Armed Forces was still engaged in partially repairing an estimated 500 destroyed houses in the Flachgau Region in order to achieve renewed rainfall resistance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.orf.at/?href=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.orf.at%2Fticker%2F335729.html|title=news.ORF.at|publisher=News.orf.at|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref>
In Poland, eight people were killed and 34 people were injured by uprooted trees.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polskieradio.pl/thenews/national/artykul112675_seven_dead_as_more_storms_ravage_poland.html|title=Polskie Radio - najlepsze radio online - Polskie Radio w internecie|work=PolskieRadio.pl|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> Two people were also killed in the Czech Republic. Power was still not completely restored by July 25 in the surrounding areas of [[Liberec]] and Bohemia.

{{redirect|Salt spring}} A '''brine spring''' or '''salt spring''' is a [[Brine|saltwater]] [[Spring (hydrology)|spring]].
Brine springs are not necessarily associated with [[halite]] deposits in the immediate vicinity. They may occur at valley bottoms made of clay and gravel which became soggy with brine seeped downslope from the valley sides.<ref>{{cite book |first= W.C. |last= Phalen |year= 1919 |title= Salt Resources of the United States |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=jagPAAAAIAAJ&pg=RA1-PA132 |location= Washington, DC |publisher= Government Printing Office |page= 132 |oclc= 4101987}}</ref>
Historically, brine springs have been early sources of U.S. salt production, as in the case of the [[salterns]] in [[Salt industry in Syracuse, New York|Syracuse, New York]] and at the [[Illinois Salines]].
==See also== *[[Saline seep]] *[[Salt lick]] *[[Mineral spring]]
